content:
I've been trying to play with the _include syntax to make sure I understand it, but all of my queries to http://fhir2.healthintersections.com.au/open are returning exceptions so I'm not sure if it's a problem with my queries or a problem with the server/test data. Is this a valid query to include a patients's organization when performing retrieving a patient?

[...]/Patient?_id=107&_include=Patient:organization

Based on the FHIR docs I believe this is the correct syntax but the reference server seems to disagree.

Test query: http://fhir2.healthintersections.com.au/open/Patient?_id=107&_include=Patient:organization
I think that's bug a in @Grahame Grieve SQL script.
*a bug* not *bug a*
The syntax is correct.
Is this a valid query: [...]/Encounter?_lastUpdated=ge2016-06-25T14:15:16&_include=Encounter:location
Try it here: http://fhir3.healthintersections.com.au/open
and yes.
thx Chris

Both the queries are valid, it looks like the healthintersections.com.au only supports searches through _search, so you can change your request like below http://fhir3.healthintersections.com.au/open/Patient/_search?_id=107&_include=Patient:organization&_format=json

It's working fine as far as I can tell with this
http://fhir3.healthintersections.com.au/open/Patient?_id=107&_include=Patient:organization
yes. don't need _search

Sorry my bad, the URL without _search was not working couple of hours ago and was returning "no document found at /open/Patient which was when I tried using _search(as suggested from its web app UI). Now both seem to work. Ignore my comment.

When listing multiple includes, is it preferred to say ?_include=SomeResource:searchparam,SomeOtherResource:searchparam or ?_include=SomeResource:searchparm&_include=SomeOtherResource:searchparam or are both fine?
My understanding from http://hl7.org/fhir/search.html#include was that the latter should be used
It does show that in one example, but I wasn't sure whether that precluded the comma syntax - which is more concise.
@Grahame Grieve @Ewout Kramer @Josh Mandel ?
My take is that since we haven't document to the, syntax it doesn't exist. I think I've come to that conclusion before (quietly to myself).
I guess on the grounds that it's an "and" rather than an "or" - and that "or" doesn't make sense, it would have to be that way, wouldn't it? Thanks for prompting me to think it through :)
I don't think we've commented on this.

I guess on the grounds that it's an "and" rather than an "or" - and that "or" doesn't make sense, it would have to be that way, wouldn't it? Thanks for prompting me to think it through :)

I agree it should be option B, with the same gut feeling as Lloyd is having.

We're seeing a FHIR server which supports _includes in the form of Observation?_include=Observation:patient,Observation:practitioner (note the comma separated list) instead of Observation?_include=Observation:patient&_include=Observation:practitioner . It seems they were reading something in http://build.fhir.org/search.html#revinclude which inspired this usage - nevertheless, it's wrong and not the intent of the standard. Have we seen this syntax implemented anywhere else ? (if so, some clarification in the standard may be in order)
Change request would be a good idea
Hi @Lloyd McKenzie It is actually my vendor's server who implemented this way, is your comment to suggest we should ask them to change it? That is how I am reading it.
I'm asking for a change request against the FHIR specification for us to clarify whether this is allowed for _include or not.

I'd strongly argue against it, "," is the logical-or delimiter in FHIR search, which isn't applicable here. If we accept this 'shortcut notation', then one could argue that the use of , would also be applicable within all sorts of other lists of parameter values. Sounds like a bad idea to me.
(deleted)
(deleted)
